column23: +ACI-Maintaining reliable and secure electricity services while seeking to rapidly decarbonize power systems is a key challenge for countries throughout the world. More and more countries are becoming increasing dependent on reliable and secure electricity supplies to underpin economic growth and community prosperity. This reliance is set to grow as more efficient and less carbon intensive forms of power are developed and deployed to help decarbonize economies.

column1: Energy is necessary for creating the conditions for economic growth. It is impossible to operate a factory
column3: grow crops or deliver goods to consumers without using some form of energy. Access to electricity is particularly crucial to human development as electricity is
column5: indispensable for certain basic activities
column6: such as lighting
column7: refrigeration and the running of household appliances
column8: and cannot easily be replaced by other forms of energy. Individuals' access to electricity is one of the most clear and un+AC0-distorted indication of a country's energy poverty status.

column1: Electricity access is increasingly at the forefront of governments' preoccupations
column2: especially in the developing countries. As a consequence
column3: a lot of rural electrification programs and national electrification agencies have been created in these countries to monitor more accurately the needs and the status of rural development and electrification.

column1: Use of energy is important in improving people's standard of living. But electricity generation also can damage the environment. Whether such damage occurs depends largely on how electricity is generated. For example
column2: burning coal releases twice as much carbon dioxide +AC0- a major contributor to global warming +AC0- as does burning an equivalent amount of natural gas.+ACI-

column13: +ACI-Total population growth rates are calculated on the assumption that rate of growth is constant between two points in time. The growth rate is computed using the exponential growth formula:

column1: r +AD0- ln(pn/p0)/n
where r is the exponential rate of growth
column3: pn is the end period population
column4: p0 is the beginning period population
column5: and n is the number of years in between. Note that this is not the geometric growth rate used to compute compound growth over discrete periods.

column12: +ACI-Population estimates are usually based on national population censuses

column1: Errors and undercounting in census occur even in high+AC0-income countries.  In developing countries errors may be substantial because of limits in the transport
column3: and other resources required to conduct and analyze a full census.

column1: The quality and reliability of official demographic data are also affected by public trust in the government
column2: government commitment to full and accurate enumeration
column3: confidentiality and protection against misuse of census data
column4: and census agencies' independence from political influence. Moreover
column5: comparability of population indicators is limited by differences in the concepts
column6: definitions
column7: collection procedures
column8: and estimation methods used by national statistical agencies and other organizations that collect the data.

column1: The currentness of a census and the availability of complementary data from surveys or registration systems are objective ways to judge demographic data quality. Some European countries' registration systems offer complete information on population in the absence of a census.
The United Nations Statistics Division monitors the completeness of vital registration systems. Some developing countries have made progress over the last 60 years
column2: but others still have deficiencies in civil registration systems.

column1: International migration is the only other factor besides birth and death rates that directly determines a country's population change. Estimating migration is difficult. At any time many people are located outside their home country as tourists
column3: or refugees or for other reasons. Standards for the duration and purpose of international moves that qualify as migration vary
column4: and estimates require information on flows into and out of countries that is difficult to collect.

column4: and migration by age and sex through 2050

column6: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
column7: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects: 2022 Revision+ADs- or derived from male and female life expectancy at birth from sources such as: (2) Statistical databases and publications from national statistical offices+ADs- (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics.
column8: Health: Mortality
column11: +ACI-Life expectancy at birth used here is the average number of years a newborn is expected to live if mortality patterns at the time of its birth remain constant in the future. It reflects the overall mortality level of a population
column12: and summarizes the mortality pattern that prevails across all age groups in a given year. It is calculated in a period life table which provides a snapshot of a population's mortality pattern at a given time. It therefore does not reflect the mortality pattern that a person actually experiences during his/her life
column13: which can be calculated in a cohort life table.

column1: High mortality in young age groups significantly lowers the life expectancy at birth. But if a person survives his/her childhood of high mortality
column2: he/she may live much longer. For example
column3: in a population with a life expectancy at birth of 50
column4: there may be few people dying at age 50. The life expectancy at birth may be low due to the high childhood mortality so that once a person survives his/her childhood
column5: he/she may live much longer than 50 years.+ACI-
column6: +ACI-Mortality rates for different age groups (infants
column7: children
column8: and adults) and overall mortality indicators (life expectancy at birth or survival to a given age) are important indicators of health status in a country. Because data on the incidence and prevalence of diseases are frequently unavailable
column9: mortality rates are often used to identify vulnerable populations. And they are among the indicators most frequently used to compare socioeconomic development across countries.+ACI-

column25: +ACI-Gross domestic product (GDP) from the expenditure side is made up of household final consumption expenditure
column27: gross capital formation (private and public investment in fixed assets
column30: and net exports (exports minus imports) of goods and services. Such expenditures are recorded in purchaser prices and include net taxes on products.+ACI-
column32: +ACI-Because policymakers have tended to focus on fostering the growth of output
column33: and because data on production are easier to collect than data on spending
column34: many countries generate their primary estimate of GDP using the production approach. Moreover
column35: many countries do not estimate all the components of national expenditures but instead derive some of the main aggregates indirectly using GDP (based on the production approach) as the control total.

column1: Data on exports and imports are compiled from customs reports and balance of payments data. Although the data from the payments side provide reasonably reliable records of cross+AC0-border transactions
column2: they may not adhere strictly to the appropriate definitions of valuation and timing used in the balance of payments or corresponds to the change+AC0-of ownership criterion. This issue has assumed greater significance with the increasing globalization of international business. Neither customs nor balance of payments data usually capture the illegal transactions that occur in many countries. Goods carried by travelers across borders in legal but unreported shuttle trade may further distort trade statistics.+ACI-

Electricity consumption is equivalent to production less power plants' own use and transmission

column33: +ACI-An economy's production and consumption of electricity are basic indicators of its size and level of development. Although a few countries export electric power
column34: most production is for domestic consumption. Expanding the supply of electricity to meet the growing demand of increasingly urbanized and industrialized economies without incurring unacceptable social
column36: and environmental costs is one of the great challenges facing developing countries.

column1: Modern societies are becoming increasing dependent on reliable and secure electricity supplies to underpin economic growth and community prosperity. This reliance is set to grow as more efficient and less carbon intensive forms of power are developed and deployed to help decarbonize economies. Maintaining reliable and secure electricity services while seeking to rapidly decarbonize power systems is a key challenge for countries throughout the world.
In developing economies growth in energy use is closely related to growth in the modern sectors +AC0- industry
column3: and urban areas +AC0- but energy use also reflects climatic
column5: and economic factors (such as the relative price of energy). Energy use has been growing rapidly in low+AC0- and middle+AC0-income economies
column6: but high+AC0-income economies still use almost five times as much energy on a per capita basis.

column1: Governments in many countries are increasingly aware of the urgent need to make better use of the world's energy resources. Improved energy efficiency is often the most economic and readily available means of improving energy security and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.+ACI-
column2: +ACI-Data on electric power production and consumption are collected from national energy agencies by the International Energy Agency (IEA) and adjusted by the IEA to meet international definitions. Data are reported as net consumption as opposed to gross consumption. Net consumption excludes the energy consumed by the generating units. For all countries except the United States
column3: total electric power consumption is equal total net electricity generation plus electricity imports minus electricity exports minus electricity distribution losses.

column1: The IEA makes these estimates in consultation with national statistical offices
column4: and national energy experts. The IEA occasionally revises its time series to reflect political changes
column5: and energy statistics undergo continual changes in coverage or methodology as more detailed energy accounts become available. Breaks in series are therefore unavoidable.+ACI-

column1: NY.GDP.PCAP.CD
column5: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

column1: NY.ADJ.NNTY.CD
column5: Adjusted net national income is GNI minus consumption of fixed capital and natural resources depletion.
column6: +ACI-World Bank staff estimates based on sources and methods in World Bank's +ACIAIg-The Changing Wealth of Nations: Measuring Sustainable Development in the New Millennium+ACIAIg- (2011).+ACI-
column7: Economic Policy +ACY- Debt: National accounts: Adjusted savings +ACY- income
column8: Annual
column10: +ACI-Adjusted net national income complements gross national income (GNI) in assessing economic progress (Hamilton and Ley 2010) by providing a broader measure of national income that accounts for the depletion of natural resources.

column1: Adjusted net national income is calculated by subtracting from GNI a charge for the consumption of fixed capital (a calculation that yields net national income) and for the depletion of natural resources. The deduction for the depletion of natural resources
column5: reflects the decline in asset values associated with the extraction and harvesting of natural resources. This is analogous to depreciation of fixed assets.+ACI-
column6: +ACI-Adjusted net national income is particularly useful in monitoring low+AC0-income
column7: resource+AC0-rich economies
column8: like many countries in Sub+AC0-Saharan Africa
column9: because such economies often see large natural resources depletion as well as substantial exports of resource rents to foreign mining companies. For recent years adjusted net national income gives a picture of economic growth that is strikingly different from the one provided by GDP.

column1: The key to increasing future consumption and thus the standard of living lies in increasing national wealth +AC0- including not only the traditional measures of capital (such as produced and human capital)
column2: but also natural capital. Natural capital comprises such assets as land
column4: and subsoil resources. All three types of capital are key to sustaining economic growth. By accounting for the consumption of fixed and natural capital depletion
column5: adjusted net national income better measures the income available for consumption or for investment to increase a country's future consumption.+ACI-
column6: +ACI-Adjusted net national income differs from the adjustments made in the calculation of adjusted net savings
column7: by not accounting for investments in human capital or the damages from pollution. Thus
column8: adjusted net national income remains within the boundaries of the United Nations System of National Accounts (SNA).

column1: The SNA includes non+AC0-produced natural assets (such as land
column3: and forests) within the asset boundary when they are under the effective control of institutional units. The calculation of adjusted net national income
column5: energy
column6: and mineral depletion
column7: as well as consumption of fixed capital
column8: thus remains within the SNA boundaries. This point is critical because it allows for comparisons across GDP
column10: and adjusted net national income+ADs- such comparisons reveal the impact of natural resource depletion
column11: which is otherwise ignored by the popular economic indicators.+ACI-
